title: Part A

Select a point value to view scoring criteria and examples or to score the response.

Each criterion is achieved independently.
descriptions:
The response does not accomplish the task set by part A of the question.

Part A: Describe one example of a migration of Afro-descended people prior to 1860.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • The transatlantic slave trade, including the Middle Passage, involved transporting Africans against their will across the Atlantic Ocean.

  • The forcible relocation of African Americans from the upper South to the lower South occurred during the cotton boom of the early nineteenth century.

  • There was a forced migration of African Americans during the first half of the nineteenth century that became known as the Second Middle Passage.

  • Around 30,000 African Americans used the Underground Railroad to flee enslavement and resettle in free territories in the United States North, Canada, and Mexico.

The response accomplishes the task set by part A of the question.

Part B: Describe one cause of a migration of Afro-descended people between 1900 and 1970.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • African Americans from the United States South migrated to the North for better safety and economic opportunities, especially opportunities related to the wartime boom in factory-based employment.

  • Marcus Garvey founded the Universal Negro Improvement Association (UNIA) and the Back-to-Africa movement as a way for African Americans to escape racial violence and discrimination.

  • Afro-Caribbeans were affected by the decline of Caribbean economies during the First World War, so they migrated to the United States for economic opportunity.

The response accomplishes the task set by part B of the question.

Part C: Explain how the migration of Afro-descended people to the United States influenced a social or cultural change in the twentieth century.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • Afro-Caribbean immigrants in the early twentieth century created new blends of Black culture in the United States by introducing religious, linguistic, and cultural diversity to African American communities.

  • Many of the Afro-Caribbean intellectuals contributed to an increase in radical intellectual thought by infusing their experiences of Black empowerment into radical Black social movements of the time.

  • To protest colonialism and the assimilation of Black people into European culture, French-speaking Caribbean and African writers founded the Négritude movement. The movement emphasized cultural pride and the political liberation of Black people. Movement proponents rejected the idea that colonialization civilized subjects.

  • Black and mixed-race Latin Americans founded the Negrismo movement. The movement celebrated African contributions in Latin American music, folklore, literature, and art, and emphasized cultural pride and liberation. Movement proponents believed that racial ideologies underpinned colonial exploitation and systems of coerced labor.

The response accomplishes the task set by part C of the question.
